Immobilized V-MIL-101 on modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles as heterogeneous catalyst for epoxidation of allyl alcohols and alkenes Faezeh Farzaneh ⁎ Yasaman Sadeghi Department of Chemistry, Alzahra University, P.O. Box 1993891176, Vanak, Tehran, Iran Department of Chemistry Alzahra University P.O. Box 1993891176 Vanak Tehran Iran ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +98 21 88258977; fax: +98 21 8804134. Graphical abstract As a new heterogeneous catalyst, Fe3O4 nanoparticles were prepared and modified with sodium silicate and (3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane (APTMS) followed by complexation with V-MIL-101 and designated as Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL-101. It was characterized using FTIR, TEM, and VSM techniques. The Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL-101 was found to successfully catalyze the epoxidation of allyl alcohols and alkenes with tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) in moderate to high yields. The epoxidation of trans-stilbene, norbornen, cyclooctene, geraniol, trans-2-hexene-1ol and 1-octene-3-ol with 100% selectivity is promising. Investigation of the stability and reusability of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 revealed the heterogeneity character of the catalyst with no desorption during the course of epoxidation reactions. High yields, clean reactions, ease of catalyst separation and recyclability of the solid catalyst are some advantages of this method. Keywords Epoxidation catalyst Allylic alcohols Alkenes V-MIL101 Magnetic nanoparticles 1 Introduction Catalytic epoxidation of allyl alcohols and alkenes is an important synthetic method for both industry and academics. The use of transition-metal complexes as catalysts for epoxidation reactions is still interesting because of their role in understanding of the relevant biologically reactions [1]. Among which, study of the epoxidation of alkenes and especially allyl alcohols catalyzed by vanadium complexes with different ligands is of fundamental importance [2]. Utilization of oxovanadium(IV) compounds as oxidation catalysts was first discovered by Katsuki [3] in regioselective epoxidation of allylic alcohols with tert-butyl hydroperoxide as oxidant [4]. During the last decades, many research works have been focused on the synthesis of different vanadium(IV) type coordination compounds with Schiff base ligands as catalyst for epoxidation either in homogeneous or heterogeneous environment [5,6]. Recently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) [7] have attracted considerable attention for their potential applications in areas, such as gas storage [8], separation [9], sensors [10], ion exchangers [11], catalysis [12], adsorption volatile organic compounds [13] and drug delivery [14] due to their structures, which contain large vacancies, high surface areas, crystalline open structures, and tunable pore size by varying the type of metal source or organic linkers [15]. The MIL-n family of materials (MIL: Materials of the Institute Lavoisier) is a group of MOFs, originally developed by Serre’s group [16]. Different metal-MIL, such as Cr-MIL-101 [17], Fe-MIL-101 [18], Al-MIL-101 [19] and V-MIL-101 [20] have been reported in this regard. The metal MIL-101 materials have a zeotype crystal structure including two kinds of cages. They have multiple transition metal sites and large surface areas, which can be activated by heating in vacuum [21]. MIL-101 materials have been used as adsorbents, column packing materials and catalysts [22,23]. Due to easier recovery and recycling of reaction catalysts in the heterogeneous processes, most efforts have been focused toward the heterogeneous processes or heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts. Therefore, different solid supports, such as microporous [24,25] or mesoporous materials [26], polymers [27,28], silica and silicate layers [29] and magnetic nano particles [30] have been used. The Fe3O4 nanoparticles are known as excellent supports for heterogenization of homogeneous catalysts by immobilization of homogeneous catalysts on their surfaces. Notably, functionalized MNPs have recently been employed as catalysts for different organic reactions [31–35]. Preparation of immobilized V-MIL-101 on modified iron oxide nanomagnetic particles and application as heterogeneous epoxidation catalyst is described in this presentation. To the best of our knowledge, there has been no report on the immobilization of MOF on modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles in literature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All materials were of commercial reagent grade and used without further purification. Acetonitrile, vanadium(III) chloride (VCl3), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), methanol, terephthalic acid, norbornene, cyclohexene, styrene, alpha-methylstyrene, trans-stilbene, cinnamyl alcohol, sodium chloride (NaCl), trans-2-hexen-1-ol, 1-octene-3-ol, sodium silicate (Na2SiO3), ferric chloride (FeCl3), ferrous chloride tetrahydrate (FeCl2·4H2O), ammonium hydroxide (25%), hydrochloric acid, glycerol and 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) and tert-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 80%) were obtained from Merck Chemical Company. Cyclooctene and geraniol were purchased from Sigma and Aldrich, respectively. 2.2 Characterization FT-IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer using KBr pellets over the range of 4000–400cm−1. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken by Zeiss-EM10C-100KV. Scanning electron micrograph (SEM) images were taken by XL-30 Phillips (1992). Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using a vibrating sample magnetometer (VSM) (BHV-55, Riken, Japan) in the magnetic field range of −8000Oe to 8000Oe at room temperature. Vanadium and iron were determined by atomic absorption on a Chermo double beam instrument. Epoxidation products were analyzed by GC and GC–Mass using Agilent 6890 series with a FID detector, HP-5, 5% phenylmethylsiloxane capillary and Agilent 5973 network, mass selective detector, HP-5 MS 6989 network GC system. 2.3 Preparation of magnetic nanoparticles (Fe3O4: MNPs) The magnetite nanoparticles (Fe3O4: MNPs) were prepared according to the previously reported method [35] with some modifications. A solution of FeCl2·4H2O (0.86g) and FeCl3 (1.40g) in deionized water (40mL) was stirred at 85°C for 30min under nitrogen gas. Upon addition of ammonium hydroxide (25%, 3mL), the solution color turned from light brown to black. After stirring for 20min under these conditions, the solution was cooled to room temperature followed by filtration. The magnetite precipitate was washed twice with H2O and sodium chloride (0.02M) solution. 2.3.1 Coating magnetic nanoparticles with silica (Fe3O4@SiO2) A mixture of sodium silicate (9.50g in 50mL deionized water) containing MNPs (1.00g) of nanoparticles was stirred for 30min at room temperature and 20min at 80°C. The solution pH was then adjusted at 6–7 using dilute HCl (2M) solution. The precipitate (Fe3O4@SiO2) was separated and washed several times with H2O by magnetic decantation followed by dispersion in 50mL of methanol. 2.3.2 Functionalization of silica coated nanoparticles with APTMS (Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS) Glycerol (20mL) was added to a suspension of Fe3O4@SiO2 (2g in methanol (20mL) and H2O (0.13mL) and the resultant mixture was kept under ultrasound for 30min. Then, 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane (APTMS) (0.84mL) was added to the resultant solution, followed by heating at reflux at 80–90°C for 3h. The obtained modified nanomagnetic as nanospheres was washed with deionized water and methanol respectively, and then dried at room temperature. 2.4 Preparation of V-MIL-101 V-MIL-101 was prepared according to the procedure described previously [20]. VCl3 (0.20g) and terephthalic acid (0.17g) were dissolved in DMF (2mL) in a 10mL Pyrex tube. The tube was sealed and heated in autoclave at 150°C for 24h. After cooling to the room temperature, the green precipitate was filtered, washed with DMF and dried in air. V-MIL-101 with formula [V3OCl(C3H7NO)2(C8H4O4)3]·3.1C3H7NO·10H2O·0.1C8H6O4 was obtained. Anal. Calc.: for C40.1H68.1ClN5.1O28.5V3 (M =1265.96gMol−1): C 41.72, H 4.56, N 9.80: found C 41.74, H 4.72, N 9.85%. 2.5 Immobilization of V-MIL-101 onto (Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL101) To a stirring solution of V-MIL-101 (0.08g in 16mL DMF), Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS (0.19g) was added and the mixture heated at 90°C for 24h. The solid was then magnetically separated and washed twice with DMF. After drying of the solid at room temperature, Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 was obtained as a brown solid. 2.6 Catalytic epoxidation, general procedure All epoxidation reactions of the allyl alcohols (geraniol, cinnamyl alcohol, trans-2-hexen-1-ol and 1-octene-3-ol) and alkenes (norbornene, cyclohexene, cyclooctene, styrene, -methylstyrene and trans-stilbene) were carried out in a round bottom flask equipped with a magnetic stirrer and a water-cooled condenser. Typically, Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 (containing %2.5V) (40mg) designated as catalyst 1 in acetonitril (5mL), and substrate (20mmol in 5mL acetonitrile) were mixed. TBHP (24mmol) was then added and the mixture was heated at reflux for several hours. After separation of the catalyst by means of an external magnet, the filtrate plus authentic samples were subjected to GC and GC–Mass analyses. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst synthesis and characterization The V-MIL-101 (V-MOF) was prepared under hydrothermal conditions (Scheme 1 a). The catalyst was synthesized by preparation of Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs) by precipitation of iron(II) and iron(III) ions, using sodium silicate in acidic solution [36] and subsequent coating of Fe3O4 with silica to Fe3O4/SiO2 core–shell particles (Scheme1b). The coating procedure was carried out for two reasons. First, the SiO2 shell can effectively prevent the aggregation and chemical degradation of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles in a harsh liquid environment. Second, the surface SiOH groups can be modified by functionalization with desired organic groups. Therefore, the surface was then functionalized with APTMS [37] and the vanadium MOF was finally immobilized on the modified iron oxide and designated as MNPs@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 (Scheme 1c). Recently, the experimental and theoretical studies on the adsorption of pyridine on MIL-101 has shown that the substitution occurred by removal of one water molecule (as solvent) coordinated to the Cr-MIL-101) [38]. Based on this result, it seemed that the nitrogen of immobilized amine group was responsible for removing one DMF molecule (as solvent) coordinated to the V-MIL-101. The FT-IR spectra of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@SiO2, Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS, V-MIL-101 and Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@ V-MIL-101 before and after using as catalyst are shown in Fig. 1 a–f, respectively. For Fe3O4 magnetic nanoparticles (MNPs), observing a broad peak with relatively low intensity centered at the regions 3421 and 1622cm−1 should be attributed to the FeOH groups of the surface or the adsorbed water stretching and bending vibrations. The peak at 583cm−1 is also attributed to the FeO vibrations [37,39,40] (Fig. 1a). After modification of MNPs with sodium silicate designated as MNPs@SiO2, a relatively strong peak is observed at 1100cm−1 in its spectrum due to SiOSi and SiOH stretching vibrations (Fig 1b) [41]. In the spectrum of functionalized MNPs@SiO2 with APTMS (designated as MNPs@SiO2@APTMS), two bands appearing at 2870 and 2920cm−1 are related to the CH stretching vibrations (Fig 1c) [42]. The FT-IR spectrum of V-MIL-101 shown in Fig. 1d is consistent with those reported previously [37]. It shows vibrations corresponding to 1660–1650cm−1 (DMF), 1440, 1620cm−1 (COO symmetric and asymmetric), weak bands in the spectral region of 700–400cm−1 most likely due to in-plane and out-of plane bending modes of COO groups [41], 1520cm−1 (CC), 940cm−1 (VO) and the weak bands appearing at 887 and 764cm−1 relating to the stretching vibrations of CC groups and the out-of-plane deformation vibrations of benzene ring CH groups [42]. Observation of bands at 948 and 610cm−1 in the spectrum of MNPs@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101, attributed to the VO and COO vibrations, are consistent with the immobilization of V-MIL-101 on the modified MNPs@SiO2@APTMS nanoparticles (Fig 1d,f) [20,41–43]. The X-ray diffraction powder pattern (XRD) of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 is shown in Fig. 1S (see Supplementary). The diffraction peaks can be assigned to the planes of spinel structured (JCPDSNo.19-0629) [35,42]. The magnetic properties of the prepared nanomaterials were investigated by means of vibrating sample magnetometry (VSM). Data obtained for the hysteresis loops of the materials at room temperature (Fig. 2 ) exhibits magnetization curves of MNPs, MNPs@APTMS and MNPs@APTMS@V-MIL-101 either before or after use as catalyst. Whereas the magnetization curve of Fe3O4 nanoparticles showed no remanence effect (superparamagnetic property) with saturation magnetization of about 25emu/g (Fig. 2a), superparamagnetic behavior decreased to saturation magnetization of about 12emu/g after coating of the magnetite nanoparticles with amino–silane (Fig. 2b). Based on the obtained difference, coupling of a rather small amount of amino–silane to the magnetic nanospheres surface is concluded. Afterward, by means of amino–silica nanoparticles surface modification with V-MIL-101, the exhibited superparamagnetic properties was found to decrease to saturation magnetization of about 11emu/g. Recall that the superparamagnetic properties of MNPs@APTMS@V-MIL-101 is critical in preventing aggregation and enabling it to redisperse rapidly upon removing the magnet. The superparamagnetic properties of MNPs@APTMS@V-MIL-101 before and after using as epoxidation catalysts are shown in Fig. 2c and d, respectively [41–44]. With such high magnetization property of MNPs@APTMS@V-MIL-101 after using as catalyst, the catalyst could be easily separated from solution under an external magnetic field. The SEM image of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 shows the formation of some spherical particles with about 27–38nm (see Supplementary, Fig. S2). The transmission microscopy (TEM) image of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL101 is presented in Fig. 3 . The magnetic core shell nanoparticles (Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL101) with about 8–10nm in diameter is evident in this Figure. 3.2 Catalytic studies The catalytic performance of V-MIL-101 and Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 was studied in the epoxidation of norbornene as the representative substrate using TBHP as oxidant. In order to find the optimum reaction conditions, the effect of various reaction parameters, such as the amount of catalyst, reaction time and solvent were evaluated (Figs. 4–6 ), respectively. As indicated in Fig. 4, increasing the amount of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 catalyst from 10 to 40mg increases the conversion from 50 to 70% with 100% selectivity. Similarly, increasing the reaction time from 16 to 24h using 40mg of catalyst was found to increase the norbornene conversion from 48 to 70% with 100% selectivity (Fig. 5). When epoxidation of norbornene was carried out in the presence of V-MIL-101, 93% conversion with 95% selectivity was observed within 14h and using 20mg of the catalyst. As has been reported previously, solvent usually affect the conversion in homogeneous catalysis systems [45]. In our heterogeneous catalysis system, the influence of different solvents, such as acetonitrile, methanol and dichloromethane is also observed, although rather weaker under optimum reaction conditions (Fig. 6). As is shown, a decrease in conversion is observed in the order of acetonitrile>methanol>dichloromethane (Fig. 6). This trend is in the decreasing order of dielectric constants as well as boiling points of these solvents. As has been explained (vide infra), the transition state of the complexation of both hydroxyl and double bond groups to vanadium center is more polar in comparison to that of reactants. Therefore, increasing the polarity of the solvent is expected to increase the reaction rate. On the other hand, increasing the solvent boiling point seems to increase the reaction rate constant based on the Arrhenius equation. Moreover, since the one with the most transition state stabilization in acetonitrile reacts with highest in the first step, undergoes reaction with the slowest rate in the second step in which transfer of oxygen to the double bond occurs. Therefore, obtaining the highest selectivity in acetonitrile is in accord with reactivity–selectivity principle [46]. Whereas epoxidation reactions were generally efficient using TBHP as oxidant, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) proved to be inefficient under optimized conditions. This might be related to the more electrophilic character of the peroxide oxygen in TBHP. In order to determine the general applicability of the Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 catalyst, epoxidation reactions of other olefins, such as trans-stilbene, norbornene, cyclooctene, cyclohexene, α- methylstyrene and styrene under optimized epoxidation conditions were also studied (Table 1 ). When Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 (1) was used as catalyst, the conversions were 20–75% with 70–100% selectivities toward the corresponding epoxides (Table 1). As seen in Table 1, The trans-stilbene, norbornene and cyclooctene are quantitatively converted to the corresponding epoxides with 100% selectivity, (entries 1–3, Table 1). Moreover, the selectivities were found to be higher in the presence of catalyst 1 (Table 1). In the cases of styrene and cyclohexene, benzaldeyde, and a mixture of other oxidation products were also obtained in addition to the corresponding epoxides (Table 1). Particularly significant are the epoxidation results of trans-silbene and norbornene which afforded the corresponding epoxides in high yields (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). The high selectivities might be attributed to the alkene structures in which no other oxidation routes are available in these cases. On the other hand, whereas cyclooctene exclusively gives the corresponding epoxide, cyclohexene undergoes allylic oxidation and epoxidation, concomitantly (Table 1, entries 3 and 4). Such difference may have arisen from cyclooctene chair conformation in which the double bond is in one plane and all other carbons are in another plane [47]. Therefore, the allylic hydrogens of cyclooctene are less reactive in comparison to that of cyclohexene with half-chair conformation [48]. Finally, compared to α- methylstyrene, which affords epoxide in about 98% yield (Table 1, entry 5), styrene gives styrene epoxide and benzaldehyde (Table 1, entry 6) in 70% yield. As observed previously by us and others, styrene epoxide partly undergoes further oxidation to benzaldehyde as the main byproduct [49]. The epoxidation results of various allyl alcohols, such as geraniol, trans-2-hexene-1-ol, 1-octene-3-ol, and cinnamyl alcohol with catalysts 1 and 2 as heterogeneous and homogeneous catalysts, respectively under optimized reaction conditions are given in Table 2 . Obtaining 100% conversion and selectivity for geraniol and trans-2-hexene-1-ol with catalyst 1 is promising. In the case of catalyst 2, the conversion and selectivities were found to be 45–97% and 45–95%, respectively. The higher activity of allyl alcohols may be due to the initial complexation of both hydroxyl and double bond groups to vanadium center [50]. It was also found that the epoxidation conversion of geraniol either with Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS or using no catalyst (blank) were 8 and 5%, respectively. These results clearly indicate the key role of the immobilized V-MIL-101 on the modified iron nanoparticles as catalyst in epoxidation reaction. In order to make insight into the reaction mechanism, epoxidation of trans-2-hexene-1-ol was carried out in the presence of diphenylamine as a radical scavenger. Observation of no inhibition indicated that oxidation does not occur through a radical mechanism. Based on sharpless suggestion [51], both the allylic OH and double bond as well as the hydroperoxide seem to initially coordinate to the metal center. Subsequently, transfer of oxygen form the generated peroxo intermediate to the double bond affords the corresponding epoxide product [51]. The stability of the magnetically recovered Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 has been investigated by recycling the recovered catalyst and determination of the vanadium content using atomic absorption spectroscopy. Compared to the iron and vanadium contents of 13.51 and 2.15% in the fresh catalyst, these two were found to be 13.50 and 2.11%, in the used catalyst. Therefore, the vanadium content present in the filtrate should not have been significant and no catalytic activity was also observed in using filtrate solution. The reusability of the catalyst after recovery by magnetic decantation was examined with geraniol as a model for five runs. As indicated in Fig. 7 , a decrease in conversion from 100 to 98% without any changes in selectivities was observed. As shown before, the FTIR and VSM spectra of catalyst before and after using as catalyst are similar. Comparison of the prepared immobilized V-MIL-101 nanaocatalyst with some other previously reported V-MILs and V-MIL-47 [52] as catalyst for epoxidation of cyclohexene, it seems, the extent of applicability, reusability and stability of immobilized one is more than homogeneous (V-MIL 101) catalyst. 4 Conclusions In this study, V-MIL-101 immobilized on the modified iron oxide nanomagnet and designated as Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101, was characterized with FT-IR, XRD, VSM and TEM techniques. This compound was found to successfully catalyze the epoxidation of alkenes and allyl alcohols in moderate to high yields. It was also found that the selectivity and TON number of immobilized V-MIL-101 was higher than that of unimmobilized or homogeneous systems. Study of the catalyst reusability revealed that at least five epoxidation runs could be carried out without significant reduction in catalytic activity. Based on the promising advantages of magnetic nanoparticles in comparison to those of conventional catalyst supports, utilization of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 opens a new route to the immobilization of MOFs compounds for making new catalysis systems. This method provides several advantages including high yield, clean reaction, ease of catalyst separation and recyclability of the solid catalyst. Compared to the reported TONs in the conventional catalysis systems, the high TONs obtained in this research for immobilized V-MIL-101 on modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles are promising. coredata.dc:description: As a new heterogeneous catalyst, Fe3O4 nanoparticles were prepared and modified with sodium silicate and (3-aminopropyl) trimethoxysilane (APTMS) followed by complexation with V-MIL-101 and designated as Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL-101. It was characterized using FTIR, TEM, and VSM techniques. The Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@VMIL-101 was found to successfully catalyze the epoxidation of allyl alcohols and alkenes with tert-butylhydroperoxide (TBHP) in moderate to high yields. The epoxidation of trans-stilbene, norbornen, cyclooctene, geraniol, trans-2-hexene-1ol and 1-octene-3-ol with 100% selectivity is promising. Investigation of the stability and reusability of Fe3O4@SiO2@APTMS@V-MIL-101 revealed the heterogeneity character of the catalyst with no desorption during the course of epoxidation reactions. High yields, clean reactions, ease of catalyst separation and recyclability of the solid catalyst are some advantages of this method.
coredata.dc:title: Immobilized V-MIL-101 on modified Fe3O4 nanoparticles as heterogeneous catalyst for epoxidation of allyl alcohols and alkenes
